basics.name: Frank Hellwig
basics.label: Solution Architect
basics.summary: Solution Architect and business growth professional creating innovative solutions to win contracts and exceed our customers’ expectations. I am dedicated to advancing agile methodologies, cloud technologies, and software engineering in solving challenging problems and delivering solutions. I have been in the technology field for over three decades and have operated at all levels – from designing and delivering software to building a company and winning contracts for my current employer. Recent wins: DEA Bluestone ($875M) and EPA ESSET ($550M). I combine years of hard-won knowledge and intense customer engagements with my ability to clearly communicate these lessons and turn them into solutions that win business. Proposals I have authored show our customers that we understand their problems and have a vision to do it better than the last team. I speak well, write well, and deliver deeply technical issues with clarity.

work.name: GovCIO
work.summary: Within Growth Enablement Team, I deliver innovative and workable solutions to that win business for our company. I research ways to improve our Pwin and promote innovation as the means to engage new customers and bring ideas to existing customers.
highlights: Over the past year, I was the principal SA on bids totaling $1.6 billion TCV in single-award prime contracts for the U.S. Government

work.name: Huntington Ingalls Industries
work.summary: Responsible for setting the technology direction and managing innovation. Managed a team of solution architects that won business and furthered the company's technical footprint. Mentorship role to identify and promulgate technology trends and products to improve current business execution and offer competitive proposal responses.
highlights: Developed and deployed a Bid and Proposal estimation tool for B&P funding allocation
Developed and deployed an Annual Operating Plan prediction tool based on Markov modeling

work.name: Buchanan & Edwards
work.summary: Corporate leadership role as a technology evangelist designing, developing, and delivering enabling cloud and on-premises platforms for the Department of Defense, Department of State, and the Department of Justice. Responsible for business development, program execution, internal research and development, corporate engineering initiatives, and technology accelerators.
highlights: Leading technologist winning a $100M contract for the U.S. Marine Corps Recruiting Information Support System (MCRISS). Executed on the project using an Electron-based implementation.
Designed, developed, and deployed (including ATO) the first public cloud application for the U.S. Department of State
Developed and delivered the original version of the State Department’s Smart Traveler iOS and Android application giving international travelers quick access to State Department information feeds
Designed and developed a prototype emergency management system using PhoneGap for single- source deployment to both Apple and Android devices

Lead a team that developed and delivered the Public Diplomacy Implementation Plan application to all U.S. Embassies around the globe via Microsoft Azure - including advanced technology from Expert AI providing Natural Language Analysis in summarizing implementation plans

work.name: LynxBridge
work.summary: Founded a small fifteen-person consulting company focused on providing skilled consultants in both the public and private sectors. As the CEO, managed technical delivery, payroll, business development, corporate and financial compliance, and secured our GSA Schedule 70 contract.
highlights: Enterprise software architect on the Blue Devil Block 2 program. This Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance platform was a 350-foot airship with 2,000 pounds of intelligence equipment
Chief software architect for the Vigilant program, a Northrop Grumman effort providing a collaborative intelligence system for first responders and border security for North Africa

Principal engineer for various Northrop Grumman programs providing intelligence to the war fighter using mobile devices including iPhones and iPads. Provides geospatial intelligence with connectivity to back-end intelligence systems

Corporate leadership role as a technology evangelist designing, developing, and delivering enabling cloud and on-premises platforms for the Department of Defense, Department of State, and the Department of Justice

work.name: Wells Landers
work.summary: Project lead supporting the Defense Common Ground Station for the Army (DCGS-A). Extensive and detailed programming experience integrating the DCGS metadata catalog in an enterprise-wide architecture. Created a Google Earth interface in Java to DCGS-A that displayed intelligence data on the Google Earth globe. This gave the war fighter an easy-to-navigate interface for searching and viewing signals intelligence, imagery, and IEDs.

verbose.overview: Consultant to Northrop Grumman Electronic Systems in Linthicum, MD. Principal engineer for the following IRAD efforts:
highlights: Leverage Web 2.0 technology and syndication along with Ericsson mobile technology to bring intelligence data to the warfighter via ad hoc mobile networks using off-the-shelf devices.

Create a global VPN-based lab for both Northrop Grumman users and external partners. Used Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance to create both the VPN and internal networks. Effort required firm understanding of network concepts in a large enterprise.

Installed Maven component repositories using Archiva, Artifactory, and Nexus. Championed corporate adoption of component-ware and component-based builds centered around Maven and Maven repository managers. Not so much a technical challenge as a cultural shift.

As software lead, created the development environment for the Advanced Projects Group by introducing Subversion for configuration management, Dokuwiki for collaboration, MyDMS for document management, Eclipse and Maven for software development.

Contractual efforts focused on the Defense Common Ground Station (DCGS) and the DCGS Integration Backbone (DIB). Lead an IRAD task to create an open-source governance and implementation model of the DIB metadata catalog based on the DoD Discovery Metadata Standard (DDMS).

Led a task to render intelligence reconnaissance and surveillance metadata and data on Google Earth via KML and content feeds giving the warfighter a familiar and easy to navigate interface for searching and viewing IMINT, SIGINT, and other data types. Also experimented with ontology-based reasoning tools to derive new facts from known collected data and alert users to possible threats.

work.name: RABA Technologies
work.summary: A consulting company that originally focused on the intelligence sector and then expanded into a variety of additional government and commercial areas. As a senior member of the staff, I had experience in both winning and executing on a number of projects for our Maryland customer.
highlightsxx: Technical capture leader and technical volume lead winning a $100M intelligence contract. Partnered with Lockheed Martin, SAIC, General Dynamics, and others to create national intelligence solutions. Designed, developed, and delivered tailored access solutions for remotely networked systems. These included custom network protocol development and network firewall applications.

Internal consultant to agency wide J2EE projects. Provided mentoring, design guidance, and software development expertise to over thirty projects using BEA's WebLogic Server and Portal. Provided in-depth analysis of design patterns and researched development tools and methodologies.

Developed an OC-12 and OC-48 network analysis system consisting of a Linux device driver to capture packets, a flows parser to extract the flows and store them in a database, and a Web application to query and graphically display the information.
Developed device drivers in C running on VxWorks for the Intel IXP1200 network processor. The product was a router supporting gigabit Ethernet, Fibre Channel, and T3.

Other projects: Web-based point of sale application, Two-day turnaround for a Raytheon bug in their satellite management software, Web-based performance monitoring tools, ported the Common Imagery Processor (CIP) to an eight processor SPARC system, developed a multilingual (English, Japanese) e-commerce site, developed device drivers to process SBIRS satellite telemetry, designed and developed a multimedia management system for video, voice, and text data.

highlights: High-Speed Network Analysis System (R531) - Developed an OC-12 and OC-48 ATM and POS network analysis package consisting of a Linux device drivers to capture packets, a flows parser to extract sessions and store them in a database, and a complete Web-based application to query and graphically display the information.

High-Speed Multi-protocol Router (Entrada Networks, Inc.) - Developed device drivers and routing software for the Silverline router, a gigabit Ethernet, fibre channel, and T3 router for high speed SAN's. Utilized the Intel IXP1200 network processor running VxWorks. Wrote the routing software, telnet daemon, and gigabit Ethernet driver.
Satellite Telemetry Processing (TSI TelSys, Inc.) - Developed device drivers to process satellite telemetry of spacecraft data in SGI Origin 200 systems hosting a series of custom (FPGA) PCI cards.

work.name: Boeing Defense and Space Group
work.summary: The Hanover office of the Boeing Defense and Space Group supported the Enhanced Tactical RAdar Correlator (ETRAC) ground station for the U-2 high-altitude reconnaissance aircraft. The ETRAC system provided commanders with imagery-based battlefield intelligence derived from the Advanced Synthetic Aperture Radar System-2 (ASARS-2) radar sensor carried on board the U-2 aircraft.
highlights: Lead the team designing and developing the ETRAC Mission Planning System. This was a sophisticated graphical route and collection planning system using C and native X Window drawing primitives.

Developed the communications software for the ETRAC system. The communication system (in C) sent and received messages via a Communication System Processor (CSP) and images via a NITF Communications Interface Unit (NCIU).
Researched various approaches to mission planning for the TIER programs. Authored a trade study examining the applicability of the Air Force Mission Support System (AFMSS) for UAV missions.

work.name: GTE Government Systems
work.summary: GTE Government Systems supplied the intelligence community with complete systems and consulting. Developed several systems and applications for our Maryland and Virginia customers.
highlights: Developed applications to support Virginia intelligence agency operations. Applications were written in C and C++ for a large network of Microsoft Windows based PC's and included network communications.
Developed an X/Motif applications for Fax and telephony (SS7) analysis systems.
Minstrel/Alterstone software engineer designing real-time software for voice processing systems hosted on a 68020 VME system using the OS-9 operating system.

work.name: BiiN Federal Systems
work.summary: BiiN was a short-lived joint venture between Intel and Siemens to develop fault-tolerant computers. As a pre-sales engineer, my job was to evaluate and respond to proposals and determine how the company’s products could best serve the customer’s needs. They closed in October 1989.
highlights: Responsible for federal applications of BiiN mission critical computer systems. Extensive customer interchange including briefings and demonstrations. Additional responsibilities were the operation of internal computer systems and Ada software development for multiprocessing performance analysis.

work.name: U.S. Army
work.summary: Commissioned as a U.S. Army officer after completing the ROTC program at Northeastern University. My tour of duty was spent at Fort Meade and related National Security installations. Much of my work was supporting the Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI), a national program for detecting and destroying incoming ballistic missiles.
highlights: Managed the Secure Battle Management Processor program in support of the Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI). Evaluated secure and fault tolerant computers for battle management applications. Responsible for all technical aspects of the contractual effort: writing the Statement of Work, creating a data requirements list, and briefing the program to the SDI Organization program office.

Member of the National Test Bed Source Selection Advisory Board evaluating proposals for the National Test Bed Integration Contract. The National Test Bed was a $500M program for proving SDI hardware and software.
Developed a triple DES file encryption program for the IBM PC written entirely in assembly language.

work.name: M/A-COM
work.summary: Self-employed consultant supporting automated testing and defense products at M/A-COM.
highlights: Designed and provided engineering support on a variety of automated component test equipment. Major accomplishment was the implementation of an embedded microprocessor system for microcomputers to control custom automatic test equipment via the IEEE-488 bus.

Designed the seeker transmitter logic of the Rapidly Deployable Anti-aircraft Missile System (RADAMS) transmitter. Components included switching power supply logic, microwave magnetron control logic, and built-in test equipment to provide an integrated system for both evaluation and operational phases. Designed programmable array logic.

work.name: Frequency and Time Systems
work.summary: As part of Northeastern University's Co-Op program, I worked for a company that produced, among other products, Cesium beam frequency standards including GPS space-based clocks.
highlights: Developed two products: a phase comparator for measuring drift between atomic frequency standards and a phase noise measurement system. The phase comparator included printed circuit board design.
